1.content:
"Hello..?, Hello..?" The voice echoed through Derek's skull. He couldn't remember anything, he had been having this strange dream, something about his duty what he had to do. Then that voice, it cut through everything like a knife and his mind was left reeling. He couldn't feel the soft padding of is bed, no, it felt like he was laying on his back on the ground, something pushing painfully into his back. Yet for all the pain, he just wanted to lay here, uncaring and unseeing and go back to sleep.

"I said hello! Can you hear me?" That damn voice again, it was so insistent. Feeling something prodding at his face, Derek slowly opened his eyes and light streamed in. His eye's were blurry and unfocused, but he could see a figure fluttering in front of his face coming into focus. But as the figure became more clear his mind raced, he was still dreaming! There was a tiny woman, and she looked around the same age as him, about sixteen. But she was flying, right in front of his face. She was maybe a foot tall and as she looked at him, her pretty blue eyes filled with concern, "Are you Ok? I thought you were hurt for sure." This couldn't be happening, just minutes ago he had lain down in his bed to go to sleep. Seeing his expression, her pretty little face screwed up in concern, brushing her silky platinum blond hair out of her eyes she continued, "Are you Okay human?" Derek could barely hear her, his mind was racing as his eyes took in more of the scene. He was in the forest, somewhere deep, there was moss everywhere and the trees where massive, stretching nearly out of sight, light trickling in anywhere it could through the canopy causing a patchwork of light across the forest floor.

Slowly Derek leaned forward, his mind starting to think rationally. "Where am I?" He managed to croak out, the faerie looked a little taken aback, "Why, you're in the Ingress Forest, this is a dangerous place for humans," Maybe this wasn't so bad, Derek's old life sucked, he was one of six kids in a family where nobody gave a damn about each other, in a city where nobody gave a damn about one another. Derek was from New York, and he had grown up uncared for. It had left him bitter and cruel, and he had been more than able to hold his own in a city full of rough and tumble people. But somewhere in Derek he felt the beginnings of a conscience, something telling him maybe it was time to turn over a new leaf. Then again, maybe it was time to really let loose, watching the tiny woman continue to chide him for his lack of care was starting to piss him off, and it was starting to give him an idea too. But another part of him was telling him she could help him, and besides, maybe it was time he started acting with a little compassion. Besides, he needed to figure out where he was and where he was going.

"Look I need to know what's happened, why I'm here, I don't even know who or what you are." That seemed to annoy her a little, "My name is Celes, and I'm a Faerie." His eye's opened a little at that and despite his surprise it made sense to him. She certainly was the spitting image of a faerie, and she was certainly a pretty little thing. She wore a pretty blue dress that pushed her breasts together and showed off her long pretty legs. She fluttered about Derek her hair hanging down in her pretty face as she curiously examined him from all sides, and for his part Derek's eyes were more than busy examining her petite form. However, as she noticed his look she quickly fluttered out of reach, her face showing fear and even a little anger. "You aren't thinking of eating me are you?" she demanded. Derek was completely taken aback though a little ashamed that somehow that odd thought had passed through his mind, "Wh-what? Why would I do that?" Seeing his expression she sighed in relief, "Some creatures like to eat faeries, humans do too sometimes, I was worried because of the way you looked at me." That confused him a little, "Why would they eat you?" She looked a little afraid again, "Well... we're nutritious."

He shook his head in amazement, this was a crazy place, "So where is this forest? Is it near New York?" Celes' head turned slightly at that, "New York?" Derek couldn't help but feel a little impatient, "The Big Apple, America's Mecca, The capital of the world, you know," She stared at him blankly, "Brevis has no capital, and I don't know of any giant apples," Derek sighed in frustration, "What's Brevis?" She looked at him even more oddly, "Brevis is our world," Derek stopped dead, "World? This isn't Earth?" She quietly shook her head at him, and he sat down heavily. She quickly fluttered up to him, "Don't worry human, come with me, We'll help you get out of the forest." Derek slowly stood up, still a little shaken from the revelation, "Who's we? and my name is Derek, not human." She smiled at him and apologized in her sing song voice, "Sorry Derek, us faeries will help you though," Derek's stomach growled and she looked back at him apologetically, "Sorry, but we really can't spare any food, your a little too big, but maybe we can find you something to eat when we get you out of the forest,"

Melissa forgot how young Jessa was sometimes, sure the idea was abhorrent to all of them but the others were taking it a little better. "Well, there's nothing we can do now." Melissa said, trying to sound distressed. What was done was done, it was too late now. The more she thought about the more Melissa didn't mind that particular thorn being pulled from her side once it was said and done with. Sure the girls would be afraid for a bit, but maybe they would take things a little more serious. There was a loud whinny from Mugwumps tent, drawing her attention. "Good, at least the bastard didn't get the horse."

"We can't just let it have her!" Jessa pleaded, "Sybil is our friend!" She looked around at the others, who were all carefully avoiding her gaze. "Damn you all! We need to find her!"

"Damn it Jessa! Don't you think we want to find Sibyl?!" Ysell cried back, her face pained. "So say we find this ogre? Then what? Do you think we could kill it?"

"It doesn't matter, we need to secure the camp." Melissa interrupted, she didn't need them all arguing. "That's our number one priority, we can't all traipsing about the marshes looking for her." She shot a warning look at Jessa as she started to say something, "We can't afford to lose our supplies."

"Then let me find her!" Jessa said, tears building in her eyes. "You know I'm really quiet, and Ithko showed us lots of the marshes today." Her eyes pleading with Melissa, "I'm sure I can find my way about out there and none of those stupid creatures will be none the wiser!"

"No." Melissa declared in a voice that would brook no argument. "We can't afford to be worrying about two of us being lost, it's too late." As the tears began to roll down Jessa's face Melissa gently added, "I'm sorry."

Melissa began picking up their supplies, scattered about the camp ground, as Jessa ran crying into her tent. Ithko looked displeased, but he joined in with the others as they began picking up.

"I could look for her," He told her, "No one knows these marshes better than me."

"How many times must I say it?" Melissa said sighing, "No, you're our guide, we can afford to lose you even less." As Ithko's eyes searched her face, she understood that he didn't believe her.

"She was my friend! Don't you think this hurts me too?" She whispered angrily, pleased with how convincing she sounded.

She knew she had him as his face softened, "Sorry," he whispered back, "I didn't mean to question your intentions." Before quietly returning to his work.

Melissa didn't answer, fearing she might laugh. She couldn't believe how good she was at this. Keeping her grim face on, she set about putting the camp back to rights with the others.

It only took a few hours for them to get everything back in order. Sybil's empty tent was standing again, now converted into a storage tent. The cooking and maintenance tools were all back in their crude racks, the Ogre tracks swept away, and dinner cooking on the fire. It was right around that time Ysell discovered Jessa wasn't in her tent. Worse yet, night was nearly on them.
15111112121.title: The first loss.

choices: It was a fire, a goblin campfire!
Ithko to the rescue!
151111121211.content:
The marshes were growing darker around her, but Jessa barely noticed the strange calls and howls around her as the creatures of the night awoke. She was too busy fuming as she thought about how cowardly the others were. Sybil was their friend! How could they even think about just leaving her to be digested by some disgusting bastard ogre? She expected this from the others, they were too prissy for this, but from Melissa?

Never. Melissa was tough and brave, like Jessa wanted to be. Not cold and thoughtless like she had acted back at the camp. Jessa had cried in her tent for nearly twenty minutes before she decided to sneak out. If Melissa didn't want to find Sybil, then she would. She had slipped out of back of her tent and sneaked off into the marshes as the others cleaned the stupid camp. The sad look on Ysell's face as she gathered up Sybil's clothes made her even angrier at them, that wasn't worth spit to Jessa. Action was going to save Sybil, her action. Not moping around the camp while their friend was in trouble.

As the last sliver of the sun started to slide out of sight through trees, Jessa shivered. She had been slogging through the mud for around twenty minutes, each step and she felt like an idiot. She had completely forgotten to bring any kind of torch or lantern. How was she supposed to find Sybil if she couldn't see anything? But she still had some hope, the tracks had been growing fresher and fresher. and that gave her hope. Every step was starting to feel like she was climbing a mountain though, and the trees were growing sparser. The branches made it so much easier to pull herself free of the mud, and she was dreading the idea of not having their help. But the gods were smiling on her, and she smiled right back as she saw the big hill of rocks ahead. They would make a great vantage point to look for the ogre from.

When she reached the boulders she learned two things. One, they might not be such a great place to rest. Two, she wouldn't have to look any further for Sybil. She could hear loud snoring and muffled screaming, coming from somewhere below her.

Searching around the boulders, it didn't take her long to find the edges of a massive tunnel into the rocks and under the earth. There was just one problem. One of those boulders was rolled over the hole. That wasn't going to be enough to stop Jessa though, she had to make sure. Jessa found the widest gap she could, and began squeezing into it. It was so tight that she wasn't sure she would be able to make it through. The image of the boulder rolling slightly and crushing her ran through her mind several times before she finally managed to slide out the other side, gasping.

The cave wasn't as deep as she thought, what little daylight left was filtering into the cave, giving her a dim view. The screaming was louder now, but she couldn't figure out where it was coming from. It was echoing through the cave, making it sound like several girls were screaming their heads off all around her. Jessa climbed behind some rocks, slowly and quietly making her way deeper in and wrinkling her nose at the fetid smell wafting all around her. She saw all sorts of bones scattered throughout the cavern. Most she couldn't name, but a there were several she could, human. Looking about, wide eyed, she didn't see the rib she stepped on until after a loud crunch rang through the cavern. Jessa quietly cursed and ducked down, hiding as much of herself as she could behind the rocks laying about the edges.

There was a loud grunt and a snort as the snoring cut short, and what she had thought had been a long boulder laying in the center of the cave rolled over, an ugly head rising up to look about. The creature looked about groggily, the black pupils of it's bulbous eyes rolling across the cave. Jessa held her breath it's gaze stopped on her for a moment, and was flooded with relief as the eyes continued on. The creature was smacking it's thick grey lips, giving her glimpses of it's massive yellow jagged teeth. She remembered seeing a horn like the stubby one on it's forehead years ago, hung in a bar. It was definitely an Ogre. Now that it was turned over, Jessa could see the wriggling bulge in it's gut that could only be Sybil. Jessa flinched as the creature slapped a hand against it's belly and let out a massive belch.

"Shut up food, I try sleep!" It grumbled angrily, before laying it's head back down and shutting it's eyes. Soon enough the snoring and snorting was echoing around the cave again, but Jessa waited. It was minutes later when she finally got the courage to sneak back to exit, and she slid out a lot quicker than she slid in. Unfortunately for her, what she slid out to was now as dark as the cave. The only thing going through her mind though, was she had to tell the others she found Sybil!

She had slogged right back into the mud, following her tracks from the way she came. Her tired limbs reinvigorated by her discovery, Sybil was gonna be OK. But as the sky grew darker, she lost her tracks and bearing. Her happiness was turning into fear as all around her in the marsh heard calls and rustling. She was certain if she didn't find the others soon it would be too late for Sybil, and that would be too cruel for words. She fought the tears building in her eyes, she had to be strong. Sybil was counting on her! But just as she was losing all hope, she spotted a fire far off in the distance. The campfire! She nearly sobbed in joy as she rushed towards it.

Jessa screamed as the ground disappeared beneath her and she slid into what felt like thick watery sand. Then she remembered what Ithko had been saying back when they were all scouting. He had been warning them about all sorts of dangerous stuff in the marshes, and he had made a point out of something called quicksand. Talking about how people would slowly sink into it, until eventually it would pull them deep under the marsh and they'd suffocate. He had said it was all over the marshes, and that it got nearly as many adventurers as the creatures! She screamed again and tried desperately to turn around and climb back up the bank, but the quicksand had too strong a grip on her. In fact the more she fought the deeper she felt herself slip. Then she remembered what else he had said, the more you fought the quicker it got you. She could barely think through the terror.

"Help! Somebody HELPP MEEE!!!" Jessa screamed, trying her hardest not to move and cursing her bad luck. She was so afraid she could barely think. So she was more relieved than surprised when hands slid under her arms and began pulling her back up the slope.
151111121211.title: A Forgetful Scout

choices: As a group, time to rescue their friend.
Melissa will go alone, to say goodbye.
1511111212112.content:
"Shhhh damn it!" Ithko hissed into her ear, "You want all of the damn marshes coming down on us?" Despite chiding her, he was glad for her initial scream. He might have walked right by the little bint if she hadn't. He had been looking for her for an hour. Lucky for her he didn't mind going into the marshes at night, the marsh villagers had significantly better eyes for the night than their plains dwelling brethren. Thanks to the moon he could see about as far she could with a torch. Wrenching her up out of the mud he laid her back against a nearby tree, taking a few seconds to gather his breath.

"Ithko...?" She asked him quietly, obviously embarrassed by her mistake and his rescue. "...You forgot a torch too?"

Ithko couldn't help but laugh, "No, girl, I didn't." He groaned as he stood up, "I don't need one." She startled a little as he grabbed her wrist, and helped her up. He could imagine how disconcerting it could be out in the marshes blind.

"Besides, when you're alone out here a torch can be more trouble than good." He told her, "You worried everyone running off, we were afraid we lost two friends today." The thought of Sybil made him frown. It was his job to help those who came to the village as best he could, and he was used to losing them. But he never liked it, and she had seemed like such a nice girl. It certainly wasn't a good way to go.

"We didn't lose Sybil either Ithko!" She exclaimed, a little too loud for his liking. "I found her!"

"What? How?!" He exclaimed, a little too loud for his liking too. He was so surprised he couldn't help himself though.

"I found the Ogre's cave!" Her excitement was contagious, and he felt it building in himself. Maybe he would be successful for once, maybe these girls would actually get their quarry and make it out. "I can lead us there!" She piped up again.

"We need to go to the camp first though, and get the others." He told her, lost in thought. An ogre was no easy beast to slay, if they were lucky they could kill it while it slept.

"Let me guide you, We'll be there in no time." Ithko told her, gently turning her and grabbing her hand. He hadn't been lying about how long it would take. Lucky for all of them she had nearly made it back to the camp before her she managed to bumble into the quicksand.

The fire roared high, throwing shadows about the camp as they sat around it. Ithko had made good time, even dragging the near blind girl behind him. He had to admit, Jessa wasn't as useless as he had originally thought. His opinion of her had skyrocketed with this little stunt. Heck, he doubted a marsh girl could have done better, at least up until the quicksand. The girls were all grim faced as they listened to Jessa recount what she had found, though he could see the glimmer of hope in some of their eyes. Geslia he could see looked nervous about the idea of a midnight rescue, especially against an Ogre. Melissa looked as if she were discussing what to have for supper, which surprised him as from what he know Sybil was a good friend to her. Either way, they would have to make a decision soon. He doubted Sybil would survive till morning.



"Maybe I should go alone," Melissa declared. "It will be quieter that way, and I'll be able to get the jump on the creature." She wasn't happy Jessa had found Sybil like the others were. No, she had been hoping instead that Ithko would drag Jessa back into camp by the ear. Though it was giving her an idea. There was no turning back now, the others would want some kind of rescue mounted. So maybe Melissa could take advantage of that. Slip in while the stupid beast slept, and enjoy jilling off to Sybil being turned into soup. Gods knew that her red headed friend had been trying to throw a wrench in her plan. Maybe it would be nice to whisper it to her as she churned and screamed in the ogre's belly, acid soaking her. She could just come back and tell the others it was too late, after all, she could wait.

"Besides, it might be too late." She told them, trying her best to sound sad at the thought. "It wouldn't be worth risking a fight with an Ogre for nothing."

"We should all go!" Jessa cried, "I'm the one who found her!" She was practically drilling a hole in Melissa the way she was glaring at her. "The more time we waste the less time we have!"

"I understand that Jessa," Melissa snapped at her, she was getting tired of her holier than though crap. "But the more people come, the louder we'll be." She tried to take a more soothing tone, "You can trust me Jessa, I'll sneak in there and slice it's fat neck and me and Sybil will be back in no time."

Melissa resisted the urge to snap at her again as Jessa huffed. Maybe she was going to have to really try and save Sibyl. Which she guessed wouldn't be a bad thing entirely. She would have her bait back, and it would great for morale if they killed a bloody ogre. Heck, even if they just walked out of the marshes with an Ogre head, they'd still be pretty famous. A bunch of girls going and slaying an Ogre? Melissa had never heard of anything like that. Either way though, Melissa wanted the Dragon. An Ogre would make her famous, a Dragon would immortalize her. They'd talk of her for hundreds of years to come. The peasant girl who slayed a dragon!

"I say we save her," Ysell declared, earning an approving nod from Jessa. Geslia squeaked from beside her, obviously afraid of the idea. Everyone around the fire ignored her.

"I agree, we know where she is, and we know the beast is slumbering." Ithko added to the conversation. "I mean, it seems simple enough to me." He shrugged and looked to Melissa.

Melissa felt her anger flare up a bit, she knew she would have to make a decision. But she didn't like them thinking they had any say in the matter. She put this group together, and she was the leader. What she said goes. She just had decide what goes...
1511111212112.title: Tough Decisions

choices: That isn't the only Ogre that lives here...
Back at camp.
15111112121121.content:
"Alright." Melissa sighed and shook her head, "We all go."

There were cheers, a nod and a smile from Ithko, and a squeak from Geslia. Melissa didn't notice any of it, she too busy thinking. She wasn't entirely lying about why she didn't want them all to go. It was one thing to attack a sleeping Ogre, it was another to take a wide awake one who knew you were coming. Signalling the others to grab up their gear, she pulled Ithko aside by her tent.

"I hope you realize it's really just going to be you and me against this thing." She whispered, careful not to be overheard and making sure he knew she wasn't happy by her tone.

"If we do this right that's all we need," He cast a glance at Jessa practicing with her sword, "Besides, Jessa's proven herself to be quite resourceful."

Melissa gave him a look of disbelief, "Jessa got lucky, that doesn't mean she'll be worth a damn against an Ogre." By the way he was looking at her she could tell the fool actually meant what he said. There wasn't a day in Melissa's life that Jessa hadn't been a pain in her ass. He didn't know her like she did, Jessa was useless for everything besides what she had in store for her.

"I hope for all our sakes you're right." She huffed indignantly before pulling the tent flap aside and closing it in his face. She was going to need her armor if she was going to be battling a thrice damned Ogre.


They set out into the dark marshes, Geslia and Ysell each holding a lantern on Melissa's orders, the flame set low on each. The pair was useless for everything else, so she figured it was the least they could do. Geslia had even complained about keeping the light low, and was furious that she had to explain to her that too much light meant no surprise. No surprise meant they would likely all be killed by a damnable Ogre. She was really looking forward to finding the dragon, if only to be free of this gaggle of idiots. She kept her gaze lively, watching for eyes in the dark and dangers in the path. Luckily though they found Jessa's trail quickly, and Ithko led from there.

Sure enough they came upon the rock pile, right where Jessa had said it would be. Though Melissa was disappointed to hear Sybil was still screaming bloody murder, it looked like they were following through with the fools errand after all. She had Ysell and Geslia damper the lanterns even further. Then, as quiet as possible, the group snuck to the entrance of the den. Damnit, Melissa nearly moaned. There was that damn boulder Jessa had talked about, and it was even worse than she had made it sound. No one but Jessa would be able to slip around that.

"What the hell are we gonna do now," She hissed at Ithko, who looked like perturbed than he should have been. Maybe this would be the excuse they needed to just let Sybil be turned into Ogre shit and be done with it.

"Look there," He said, pointing to the ditch by the boulder, "He's used it so much there's a groove." He paused to make sure she saw what he meant, "With a little pushing and a little control, we ought to be able to slide it over far enough to get in."

He was right, and she cursed herself for missing it. He was proving himself far too useful, she didn't need them looking to him for answers. He was already signalling Geslia and Ysell to put their lanterns down and join him at the boulder. Melissa was really hoping this behavior didn't keep up after this, she didn't need nor want competition. Positioning herself on the other side of the boulder she waved Jessa over and gave them the go ahead. Soon after soft grunts and gasps filled the air, and then with a groan the boulder slowly slid towards her. Melissa and Jessa slowed it's roll as best they could, gasping under the weight. Finally it slid to a stop, with a much bigger gap.

Melissa placed the lantern's just inside the entrance, filling the cave with a soft gold light. The Ogre became obvious as it rolled over with a groan, it's bulging gut appearing for just a moment and eliciting even more screams from the terrified girl digesting in it.

"Ysell, Geslia, you two stay out here and keep watch." Melissa whispered, "We can't have everyone in here." Luckily there wouldn't be any argument there. A soft nod from Ysell and a sigh of relief from Geslia answered her request.

Ithko leaned in and put his mouth gently to her ear, "The skulls too thick for a blade like that, and we can't risk hurting Sybil." His warm breath tickled her ear, reminding her of the night he spent with her. "The eye or the throat, those are your best bet." She could almost feel him sliding into her again, and she sighed forgetting where she was. She wouldn't admit it, even to herself, but she was dieing to bring him back into her tent.

"Got it," Melissa said breathlessly, rubbing her now warm thighs together. This was a bad time and she knew it, but between the thought of them actually killing the Ogre, and Ithko pounding into her again like some kind of magnificent animal... it was a huge turn on. Shaking her head a little she drew her sword, and Ithko and Jessa followed her example. They stayed low to the ground, careful not to block the light and have shadows play across the cave. Then, quicker than she would have wished, they were at the beasts side. She could hear the hissing and churning of it's belly, along with Sybil's screams and crying. It was all getting her so hot, she couldn't wait to kill this bastard. She wasn't sure she wouldn't gush on the spot, but at the moment, she just didn't care. The other two stopped, and she moved on. The creature's breath stank of rotting flesh, and it's thick nostrils and lips gaped and flapped as it snored. Melissa could feel the wetness between her thighs now, and standing up she cautiously lifted her leg over the creatures body until she was standing above it's head. This was it! She was going to kill this ugly bastard! Her left hand tight around the grip, the pommel driving into her right palm, she lifted the blade up ready to drive it into it's left eye. It was greatest feeling she had ever known, the inside of her thighs were dripping wet. When all of a sudden, the snoring stopped and the beast began loudly sniffing. It's eye's flew open, the black pupils focusing on her.

Melissa drove the blade down with a scream, but to her horror the beast swung it's head to the side. The blade tore a bloody paths down the side of the Ogre's head and down it's cheek, the fatty flesh and muscle parting with a squelch. Melissa caught an image of the thick bone beneath and it's rage filled eyes, before with a howl of pain and anger it's hand slammed into her side. She hit the wall with a loud thump, rolling to the floor gasping as she tried desperately to get air into her lungs. The Ogre was climbing to its feet, but then Ithko and Jessa were on it. Slashing and screaming they cut into the beast, careful to avoid it's belly. Melissa gasped, reaching for her sword with numb hands. She was almost certain the bastard had broken a rib, and was pleased to see Ithko cut a long gash into it's thigh. A moment later though he was sent flying with a grunt, his blade clattering across the cavern floor. Melissa climbed to her knees as the creature cornered Jessa, malevolently and carefully testing her reach. The brave face was gone now, and she looked like she was going to feint. Melissa wobbled to her feet just as the Ogre's hand shot out faster than any of them could have thought possible, clutching Jessa around the waist.

Melissa winced as Jessa gave a scream of terror and dug the blade into the Ogre's wrist. It howled in pain before tearing the sword free and whipping it across the room. Melissa slowly made her towards them, careful not to drag the edge of the blade along the floor. The Ogre roared, spattering thick saliva across Jessa's face as she wriggled and screamed in it's grasp. Melissa was nearly were she wanted to be, and she caught a glimpse of Ysell and Geslia, hands over their mouths. Useless, absolutely useless, she thought as she carefully pulled herself up onto the boulder behind the Ogre. Just as the Ogre began raising the begging screaming girl to it's wide open mouth, wicked teeth gnashing, Melissa called out to it.

"Hey, you filthy bastard." She cried out, the Ogre momentarily putting off it's snack to turn and look at the dark haired girl standing beside it. Melissa was ready, and the Ogre wasn't. It's eye's went wide, and a split second later the point of her blade exploded through the right orb. It's eye exploding as the blade slid into place.

Melissa sagged as the hilt was pulled from her hand, a third of the blade hidden in the Ogre's skull. The monster rocked on it's feet, It's good eye blinking wildly and it's mouth working as if it was trying to reason out what just happened. With another Howl Melissa drove her shoulder into the pommel, smiling as the blade slid out of sight and she heard the crunch of it's skull on the point. She fell back against the wall as the Ogre's hand fell open and Jessa slipped to the ground. The Ogre careened to floor, and hit with a meaty thud.

Looking over Melissa saw Ithko nursing his own wounds on the floor, he gave her a pained smile and a wink.

"Somebody cut Sybil out damnit," She muttered, before leaning her head back against the wall and closing her eyes. She was glad no one seemed to have noticed that she had screamed in pleasure. It really was the best feeling she had ever experienced.
15111112121121.title: A Heroine in Truth.

choices: There's a small party to celebrate.
There's a night raid on the camp.
151111121211212.content:
Sybil moaned in pain, her beautiful pale skin now splotchy and red. When they had cut her out of the Ogre, she had never been so happy. She thought for sure she was going to die. Seconds later she thought she was to die again, this time out of embarrassment. She stood painfully trying to cover her naked body with Ithko in the cave. But he was kind enough to look away, and even had Ysell give her the blanket he had thought to bring for her. Sybil was torn between wearing it tightly wrapped about her, thoughts of Ithko with his arms wrapped around her filling her head. Or as loose as possible, because her skin felt like it was on fire.

The walk back to the camp felt like forever, and Yvess and Jessa carefully laid her in her furs. Which for some reason they had to find. Ithko had gone out into the night, promising to bring something back for her burns. Sybil couldn't stop blushing just thinking about it, he was so kind. Melissa meanwhile, was groaning and complaining that Geslia was wrapping her chest too tightly. For once it seemed Melissa's big tits weren't working out in her favor. Sybil laughed to herself, it looked like she had been wrong after all. Melissa had saved her, and Sybil couldn't decide if she was happy she had been wrong, or awful that she had thought Melissa would do something so horrible. The Ogre's head was impaled upon a particularly large branch in the middle of camp, she had taken a brief glance at it before they had put her in her tent. It's one eye glazed and staring blindly into the dark, the ragged flesh hanging from where it's neck had been. She was glad, though she would have preferred Mugwumps head up beside it. He had stuck his head out and blowed when he saw her, and she could tell she was surprised to see her again. She had shot the old grey bastard the dirtiest look she could muster. Her ass was still incredibly sore, and she didn't think that would change for a few days at least. She didn't dare tell the others though, they would her time in the Ogre had made her a loon. No, she'd just be sure to be careful around him in the future. Melissa called out a greeting, and Sybil heard footsteps in the camp.

Sybil pulled up her furs as Ithko pulled the tent flap aside and stepped in, a mass of purple plants in his left hand. To her amazement they were glowing, little lights all across them flickering in and out of existence.

"Lucky for you we it's night," Ithko flashed her his smile, "I wouldn't have been able to find these in the day." He craned his neck to look out the tent flap, "Your burns will be gone in just a couple days thanks to these," He told her. "The Kjuka plant only grows in the marshes, and they are hard to find even here." He gently placed the plants on the ground, "City folk pay big many for them, mostly because Kjuka are man eaters, you need to know how act around them to not be attacked."

"They seem awfully small to be man eaters," Sybil said, laughing a little. Though the thought quickly became less funny when she realized just how close she had come to being eaten.

Ithko laughed with her, "These are just the vines, they have what we need."

"Thanks... for saving me I mean." Sybil blushed and snuggled deeper into her furs, "Oh! and for this too!" Her face a deep scarlet now.

"It's nothing," Ithko couldn't stop himself from laughing at her embarrassment, "I'm glad you're OK." He flashed her his white smile.

Then Ysell stepped into the tent, a small pot and a pestle in hand.

"Feel better," Ithko said bowing his head as he stepped out and closed the flap behind him.

Sybil heard water splash in the bottom of the pot as Ysell set it down. She watched curiously as Ysell stuffed some of the vines into the pot and began mashing them with the pestle. Sybil sat quietly as Ysell worked, but it wasn't for long. After a few minutes of terse silence, Ysell put the pestle down. As she looked up, Sybil could see her eyes were wet.

"I'm glad you're alright," Ysell said, her voice a little choked as she held Sybil's hand. "You deserved that least of all of us."


Sybil smiled up at her, her own eyes wet now. Sibyl had always been such a good friend to her. Lots of the other girls didn't talk to her much back in town, since she was so serious. But Sybil did, ever since the first day they had shown up in town. Geslia was always popular, but Ysell had always been her stern guardian. Always there but never noticed. Never by Sibyl though, she had always had a kind word and an eager ear for her. She had been having a hard time dealing with Sybil being lost, and she was so happy they had actually saved her she had wanted to kiss Jessa. But that was enough of that.

Hushing Sybil she started, gently pulling Sybil's furs off helping her onto her stomach. Ysell dipped her hand into the pot, pulling out a large gob of the gooey white and purple ointment. Gently she applied it, paying extra attention of her thighs and butt. Stopping when saw Sybil's abused ass. She took special care as she applied extra to Sybil's sore rear ignoring her pained protest. The poor girl had endured so much. She was relieved though, if a little surprised at how little damage there was. Ysell had seen that club the Ogre had called a cock, and something like that she'd have thought would split a girl like Sybil. She didn't ask Sybil what happened as she helped her onto her back, trying to look busy as she applied ointment to her face. Then moving on to gently groping her breasts, noticing to her secret delight Sybil's nipples responding to her touch. Then it was her belly and thighs. The thought crossing her mind as she finished that the situation was kind of bitterly humorous. Ysell had dreamed about touching Sybil like this lots of times. Though never in this situation, she sighed as she finished up.

"Sleep well sweetie," She said as she slipped Sybil's furs over her and kissed her on her forehead. The ointment vaguely reminded her of cum, heck it even tasted salty. Looking down at poor Sybil coated in the goop, she felt herself getting a little wet. She hoped Geslia would need some relief tonight.


Sybil let out her own sigh as Ysell left. She had thought about sleeping with Ysell lots of times, Ysell had never made her attraction to her a secret. This decided it, it was definitely something she was going to try as soon as she was better. Though that didn't help her now.
151111121211212.title: Sybil's Sick Tent

choices: Jessa gets a partner of her own, even if she doesn't want it.
Morning comes and there is work to do.
1511111212112121.content:
Sybil could hear the others celebrating, and wished with all her heart she could join them. From the sounds of it they had broken open the wine cask that Froid had gifted them with as they left. ________________________________________________________________________________ ___________________________________________

GOBLINS

Goblins are a sub-species of the greenskin race, and as such their society is one in which murder, cannibalism, all-consuming self-gratification, and border-line anarchy are everyday facets of their lives. These dysfunctional and horrifying sociological symptoms become all the more exaggerated as a given goblin population grows. This could be due to a multitude of factors, ranging from the local eco-system collapse and the ensuing mass hunger, cramped living conditions, savage disposition, high male-to-female ratios, or low life-expectancy. However, it is far more likely that it stems from the general cockiness that comes from being part of a large and angry mob of flesh-hungry lunatics and rapists. When a population reaches a critical mass such as this, there are only two possible outcomes, both of which result in a re-balancing of the goblin population; tribal division and in-fighting, or reckless lust-and-hunger driven raids on neighboring territories.

Unfortunately, such is the psychology of the goblin species, that when coupled with their physiology, the absence of social taboos, high libidos and short maturity period, it should come as no surprise that goblins are capable of out-breeding nearly every other race in Brevis. info.brief_description: Derek, a normal teen, awakes in a strange world called Brevis. A story book like world.
info.description:
Derek, a sixteen year old boy one day awakes in a world entirely unfamiliar to him. The world he would soon learn is called Brevis, and it is a world straight out of a faerie tale. A world of mythical lands, patch worked with black bogs and foreboding forests, stormy oceans holding with depths that light had never seen and plains that stretched on seemingly forever, all populated with every whimsical and horrid beast ever imagined. Derek has no idea why he is here, nor does he understand just what he has stumbled into. Brevis is a world filled with danger, but it is also a world of great rewards. Derek, unhappy with his former life is unsure of what to do and how to do it, so his adventure begins. Whether he is a hero or a monster or even an insignificant blip in the annals of Brevis' history is entirely up to you.
